header.title: The New Writings of Rav Ashlag: One Precept Part 21

central_thesis: The text posits that existing individual religious customs are valid but temporary stages, serving as tools for the eventual reception of a singular, prophetic 'international religion.' This transition requires a systematic societal overhaul, beginning with global economic reform, followed by the cultivation of physical health, and finally the spiritual refinement of souls, by annulling self-serving religious deviations.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Role of Individual Religions in a Universal Framework
structure_content.summary: God permits nations to retain their religious customs, recognizing their utility for individuals. However, these are preparatory steps for a future 'international religion' that is superior and divinely ordained, described as the 'prophetic last word.'

structure_content.chapter_title: Adherence and Deviation from the Universal Principle
structure_content.summary: Denying the principle of the international religion leads to harmful digression and warrants severe punishment. Conversely, embracing this principle allows individual religious worship to be acceptable, as it aligns with the truth and serves the greater international religion.

structure_content.chapter_title: Individual Religion as a Tool for Universal Attainment
structure_content.summary: Individual religious practice must function solely as a means to reach the universal religion. If a country elevates its particular religion to an ultimate goal, its religion will be forbidden by law, and its people punished for allowing spiritual improvements to deteriorate.

The author asserts that God can change any religion through a carefully planned design. This process involves bringing the international faith to the masses by annulling self-serving 'additions that the middle class added to the religion for its own good,' revelations previously granted to prophets to ease the work of reform.

structure_content.chapter_title: Caution Against Reversing Progress and Premature Empowerment
structure_content.summary: The text addresses a hypothetical objection from 'clean minded' individuals who believe they have already removed much 'ignorance.' It warns against reverting to ignorance and cautions against simultaneously enriching poor people both materially and in knowledge, implying a staged approach to empowerment.

structure_content.chapter_title: Economic Reform as a Prerequisite for Spiritual Advancement
structure_content.summary: The first step towards the international religion is to rectify the global economy. This economic stabilization is seen as a justified means to achieve the sacred goal of uprooting 'deviated opinions' from the world. The sequence is 'healthy bodies' first, then 'good souls.'

structure_content.chapter_title: Operationalizing the Plan for Global Transformation
structure_content.summary: The author offers a 'machine' (metaphor for a system or method) to facilitate this transformation, stating that the 'work and trouble' of finding a suitable plan and implementing it with 'swift, loyal legs' falls upon the audience. Collaboration is invited to develop a successful expansion plan.

key_concepts.definition: The ultimate, lofty, and prophetic universal faith that humanity is destined to receive, transcending individual national religions.
The existing religious customs and practices of nations, which are accepted as valid initial stages but are meant to serve as instrumental tools leading to the universal religion.
The act of denying the principle of the international religion, which leads to spiritual regression and detrimental outcomes for the individual and society.
Deceitful or self-serving elaborations and practices incorporated into religions by a specific societal segment, which God intends to annul for the sake of true faith.
The global financial and material system, identified as the primary target for reform and stabilization, deemed a necessary prerequisite for spiritual and social purification.

A hierarchical principle dictating that the establishment of physical well-being and material stability ('healthy bodies') must precede and enable the cultivation of spiritual development and moral character ('good souls').

practical_system.description: The text outlines a systemic, multi-stage practical approach for global spiritual and social transformation. It begins by acknowledging and utilizing existing 'individual religions' as temporary, developmental tools. The core operative step is the 'fixing of the international economy,' which is presented as the foundational work necessary to 'uproot deviated opinions' and prepare the ground for spiritual reform. This physical/material preparation ('healthy bodies') precedes and enables the care for 'good souls.' The overarching 'machine' or system involves a 'carefully planned design' (presumably divine, but requiring human agency to implement) to annul 'middle class additions' and introduce the 'international religion.' The system implicitly requires agents ('messengers' or 'suitable people') to disseminate the plan and bring about the transformation, operating with 'swift, loyal legs' for widespread implementation.
tools: The international economy (as an object to be fixed and then a tool for reform)
'Swift, loyal legs' (dedicated individuals or organizations for implementation)

relevant_quotes.text: Eventually, they will be able to completely receive the international religion that is lofty and above them all. It is the prophetic last word.
In a word, individual religion must be set in such a way that it would be just a tool to reach the universal religion.

Though God can change any religion, and with a carefully planned design, this international faith can be brought into the midst of the masses, when God annuls all the additions that the middle class added to the religion for its own good.
First, we should fix the international economy using all the means in our hands, since the goal justifies the means, especially a sacred, difficult-to-realize goal such as this.
First, we need to create healthy bodies; then we can start taking care of good souls for those bodies.

critical_analysis.relevance: This text presents a profound esoteric vision for humanity's spiritual and social evolution, deeply relevant to traditions within Western Esotericism that seek a universal synthesis or a messianic age. The concept of an 'international religion' aligns with Hermetic universalism and the Qabalistic notion of Tikkun Olam (repair of the world), where individual spiritual paths ultimately converge. Rav Ashlag's emphasis on material prerequisites (fixing the international economy, creating healthy bodies) before spiritual elevation echoes the alchemical principle of 'as above, so below' and the need to rectify the physical vessel for spiritual work. It also resonates with the 'Kingdom of Heaven on Earth' ideal found in many esoteric movements, suggesting a practical, sequential approach to achieving a utopian spiritual state.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary audience includes advanced students and practitioners of Kabbalah, particularly those engaged with the works and philosophy of Rav Ashlag. It also appeals to esotericists interested in the socio-political implications of spiritual teachings, universalist religious movements, and the systemic, practical application of spiritual principles for global transformation. Leaders and thinkers within esoteric communities concerned with societal reform and the establishment of a new spiritual order would find this highly pertinent.
